instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message:
I'm getting my ass handed to me by this 2015 Air board. It had very light corrosion scattered in a few places, mostly around the 3V42 circuit and other PPBUS components, but not near the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> charging area, that all looks perfect and measures normally (voltage, diode.) 3V42 and PPBUS were always there and did not require any repairs to get them going. I have a normal MagSafe light, SMC reset works fine, SMC bypass causes a millisecond fan spin.

I've repaired and replaced components in every area that was even slightly damaged just to make sure there was nothing unexpectedly causing a failure. I've taken diode measurements against a good board and can't find anything off. I've reached the end of what I can do with it so if anyone has a helpful idea for a next step it would be greatly appreciated.

I have:
• 3V42
• PPBUS
• PPVRTC
• <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>
• <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
• <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
• <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>

I don't have:
• <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> (0V)
• <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> (0.346V)
• Every other voltage line on the Power Aliases page

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Does it turn on if you remove <CAPACITOR>C1300</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C1303</CAPACITOR>? do you have any corroded traces by <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>? Follow where they go. This has all the right problems to be an unsolvable nightmare, but let's try.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message:
No luck. No change after removing <CAPACITOR>C1300</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C1303</CAPACITOR>. And the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area looks perfect. All lines are making their way to the next junction and so far everything there looks good too. I did originally change <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> because <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X2_R</SIGNAL> was at 0.025V and <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X1</SIGNAL> is at 0.65V. No change after replacing that though.

This is hard because the areas that had corrosion seem pretty innocuous as far as the board turning on. The one thing that I think is hurting the cause is that there were tiny amounts of corrosion in a few different areas. It definitely wasn't concentrated on just one area, but it was things like backlight, PPBUS and 3V42.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: It must be pulsing power if the SMC bypass can cause fan spin. Check all data lines to BIOS chip and check if <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> gives a millisecond pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message:
I have a similar problem, LD, UC => no power on, no fan spin.

Green/Orange light OK, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ok, I can measure lots of activity around the SMC including 32KHz clock, also <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> ok.

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> also OK.

BIOS chip looks good, signals - voltages present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: george-a, please stop hijacking threads. If you have a question start your own new one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message:
Apologies, I thought that was the point, NOT to start new threads when a topic is already there with similar or same issue. Also I noticed those ones where unanswered for a long time and maybe there was a point in resurrecting them.

Again please accept my apologies, I didn't mean to make a mess, the contrary.

EDIT: also if you noticed on the other thread ([url]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/4099-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-macbook-air-no-power[/url]), our friend completed the discussion by adding how he reached a solution - even if it was "voodoo" as he said. And this is helpful for everybody, you for example dont need to answer the same questions all the time and we just do a search instead of thread flooding.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Just wanted to add a thought to this. I think both sides are right. I think there are TWO distinct ways to add to a current thread. One is to add your issue that is close or similar to the original poster's, and the second is to say something like, "I have the exact same problem, any progress?' The former gets chaotic pretty fast, while the latter feels reasonable and is sometimes helpful for people involved. I think the key is that it really needs to be the exact same issue. Once you start posting things like, "this is what's happening to mine" the thread gets convoluted. Hope that helps. btw, I'll update this once I ever get a chance to get back to this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is putting out around 0.7V on <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X1</SIGNAL> and 0.01V on <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X2_R</SIGNAL>

It has 0V on both PP1V2_CAM_XTALPCIEVDD and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBTLC</SIGNAL>.

Not sure which power rails I should be fighting for here. Does anyone know if <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> will still output the clock signals (<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X1</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_X2_R</SIGNAL>) even it's missing PP1V2_CAM_XTALPCIEVDD and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBTLC</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: You did not answer my questions from post #4. I still say resistors in SPI ROM data lines or corroded trace around there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Sorry, missed that. Yes, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> shoots up to about 2.6V for a split second and drops right down. All of the pins except ground on the BIOS chip are getting 3.3V but I'm assuming that doesn't tell me enough?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Does CPU Vcore come on briefly too? If yes then go and check all traces and resistors to the SPI ROM. There are a bunch of resistors in series with the data lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: CPU Vcore is not coming on. After trying it multiple times I can see a 0.001V blip. Not sure if that would qualify as anything meaningful, but that's all I'm getting.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> getting a pulse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: That line jumps up to about 0.6V for a split second.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Look very closely at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, pin 8 is the main suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Pin 8 has 3.42V. Pins 1 and 2 have 0.06V. All other pins are measuring 0V. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and the area around it looks good. Doesn't look like it got hit by anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Pin 1 and 2 should get a pulse on there. Best to check on pin 7, it should get a pulse just like you measured elsewhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Pin 7 and 1 get a pulse that got up to about 1V at times - usually around 0.5V. Pin 2 got up to almost 3V some of the time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: My suspect of SPI ROM data line is still the best guess. Remove ROM and measure all pins on diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: If this is with chip removed that all seems fine. I am out of ideas on this one. Maybe corrosion under SMC or CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Yes, that was with the chip off. Thanks, I'll keep digging. Could this just be a bad ROM chip or bad programming? And do you know if the fan would spin up without an SPI ROM chip on it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Without ROM it will power cycle on/off. I doubt the ROM will be bad <1%. Corrosion somewhere......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Ok, got it, thanks. I'll work with that and see what I can find.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: Ok, so I had decided to let this one go, but then when I was using it as a diode-measurement reference for another 00165 board I noticed that <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> was mangled and had some bad diode measurements. I replaced it and now my 3V42 line is at about 7V. Any thoughts about this? The diode measurements on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> all match a good board now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> cannot affect 3V42. No idea what is going on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: It had no 3V42 problem before I switched that. I replaced <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> and it's still at 7V. I guess I'll give up on this again. No time for extended battles.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: The original board in this thread had 3V42 or it would have been totally dead. No idea what board this is then....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No SLP
threads.message: It did have 3V42. It's the same board. It was fine until I switched out <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. Something changed in the 3V42 line when I did that. Either way, moving on.
